title: Colorful Polygon
statementHtml:
You are given an array a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an, where n≤8n≤8 and a1+a2+⋯+an≤100a1+a2+⋯+an≤100.

Construct a simple polygon∗∗ with at most 333333 vertices that has exactly

(a1+a2+⋯+an)!a1!a2!⋯an!(a1+a2+⋯+an)!a1!a2!⋯an!
different triangulations††. It can be proven that such a polygon always exists.

∗∗A simple polygon is a polygon that does not intersect itself and has no holes. In other words, no two non-consecutive edges can have common points, and consecutive edges must have exactly one common point — the vertex between them. Consecutive edges may be collinear.

††A triangulation of a polygon with mm vertices is a set of m−3m−3 diagonals that intersect only at vertices. A diagonal is a segment between two vertices which lies inside the polygon and has exactly two common points with the polygon sides — the vertices it connects.
inputSpecHtml:
The first line of each test contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤82≤n≤8) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1001≤ai≤100) — the elements of the array.

It is guaranteed that a1+a2+⋯+ana1+a2+⋯+an does not exceed 100100.
outputSpecHtml:
In the first line, output a single integer mm (3≤m≤3333≤m≤333) — the number of vertices in the polygon.

In the ii-th of the following mm lines, output two integers xixi, yiyi (−106≤xi,yi≤106−106≤xi,yi≤106) — the coordinates of the ii-th vertex of the polygon.

The polygon must be simple. The vertices may be given in either clockwise or counterclockwise order.
noteHtml:
In the first test, the required polygon has to have 4!1!1!2!=124!1!1!2!=12 triangulations. The following are all the triangulations of the example polygon.

In the second test, the required polygon has to have 5!4!1!=55!4!1!=5 triangulations.
